topics.body:
"@Princess♠Molestia":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54c997b163687259d7150400#post_54c997b163687259d7150400
[bq="Princess♠Molestia"]"@HJSDGCE":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54c996f663687248ca921b00#post_54c996f663687248ca921b00
Microsoft hologram glasses. they exist now. also Occulus rift.[/bq]
I'm going to burst *EVERYONE'S* bubble here, but the hologram glasses thing has next to no real world applications.

"Well what if I want directions?"
There's a thing called a cellphone.
"What if I want to browsing the internet on the go?"
There's a thing called a cellphone.
"What if I want to look at family pictures on the go?"
There's a thing called a cellphone.

To use an analogy it's like bluetooth headsets.  There's a pretty large market for it, *BUT* not every person on the planet uses it; sure most smartphones have bluetooth compatibility but that doesn't automatically mean everyone uses it.

"Well what about if we use the technology for cars?"
Well self driving cars are coming out next year; if a car can drive itself then why does it need a 3d display in the windshield other than to look cool.


Oculus rift has a lot of potential, but it's more along the lines of a computer mouse in that in ten years time it'll be industry standard for computers and gaming machines to have one packaged their own VR device.  What do I mean by this?  Well if you buy a dell computer in ten years it will come with a VR device that they manufactured.  If you buy a HP computer in ten years it will come with a VR device that they manufactured.  When you get down to it the Oculus is basically two small HD screens in front of the user's eyes packaged with headphones.
